abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Purpose</jats:title>
            <jats:p>This study aimed to describe physical activity (PA) via the frequency, intensity, time, type, volume, and progression (FITT-VP) principles of Native Americans (NA), it is necessary to understand their current PA. The purpose was to 1) evaluate PA levels utilizing FITT-VP principles and 2) compare the patterns of PA in NA men and women.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
            <jats:p>Recruitment and evaluation (<jats:italic toggle="yes">n</jats:italic> = 586) took place as part of the OPREVENT2 study baseline evaluation. The International Physical Activity Questionnaire–Short Form assessed frequency (days per week), intensity (walking, moderate, vigorous), and time (minutes per day). The total MET-minutes for the previous 7 d provided the volume of activity.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
            <jats:p>The NA sample was 45.8 ± 15.1 yr of age, with a body mass index of 31.5 ± 6.4 kg·m<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup>. The FIT-V corresponded to 4.7 ± 2.3 d·wk<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, walking (3.3 METs intensity), 52 ± 47 min·d<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, and 2536 ± 2203 MET·min<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The men (<jats:italic toggle="yes">n</jats:italic> = 162) reported a greater frequency of 3.2 ± 2.5 d·wk<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> (<jats:italic toggle="yes">P</jats:italic> = 0.007) of vigorous activity lasting 55 ± 50 min·d<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> compared with the women (<jats:italic toggle="yes">n</jats:italic> = 433) with 2.6 ± 2.5 d·wk<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> of vigorous activity lasting 34 ± 38 min·d<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The men reported higher MET-minutes than did the women (<jats:italic toggle="yes">P</jats:italic> = 0.0001). Overall, 71% of men and 77% of women met the recommended PA guidelines.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
            <jats:p>Given that the majority of NA report adequate walking time and frequency, interventions are needed to improve moderate- and vigorous-intensity aerobic fitness, as well as muscular strength and endurance, neuromotor, and flexibility activities.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
title: Physical Activity Levels in Six Native American Communities Using the FITT-VP Approach
